docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 7 ACTIONS: NEW TRIAL AND APPEAL [ss 125–131]

heading.title: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]
DIVISION 7 ACTIONS: NEW TRIAL AND APPEAL [ss 125–131]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]
DIVISION 7 ACTIONS: NEW TRIAL AND APPEAL [ss 125–131]

p.text: In this Division, “action” includes interpleader action.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 126] s 126 Order of the Court for new trial

leg:heading.title: Order of the Court for new trial

p.text: The Court in its discretion may, after judgment in an action, order that a new trial of the action be had if:
the parties to the action consent, or
the action is tried with a jury and on the day on which the jury gives its verdict in the action a party to the action:
in the presence of the other party, or
in the absence of the other party but after such notice as the Court thinks reasonable has been given to the other party,
makes application for the order, or
the action is tried without a jury and a party to the action:
in the presence of the other party and on the day on which judgment in the action is given, or
in the absence of the other party but after such notice as the Court thinks reasonable has been given to the other party and, in any case, within 21 days after judgment in the action is given,
makes application for the order.
[subs (1) am Act 47 of 1997 s 5 and Sch 3]

The Court may, before judgment in an action and if no verdict in the action has been entered, order, on sufficient cause being shown, that the hearing of the action be discontinued and that a new trial be had.
This section does not limit the operation of section 127A .
[subs (3) insrt Act 53 of 2008 s 3 and Sch 12[1], effective 1 July 2008]

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 126.5] Power to order new trial

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 126.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 126, s 126(1), subparas (a), (b), (c), s 126(2), s 127, s 127A.

Historically, appeals from the District Court to the Supreme Court were limited to points of law and the District Court had a general power to grant a new trial: see ss 72 and 94 of the District Courts Act 1858 and later ss 98 and 142 of the District Courts Act 1912: see Nominal Defendant v Hook (1962) 113 CLR 641 at 656–657; [1963] ALR 183; 36 ALJR 190; BC6200660 per Windeyer J. In the 1973 District Court Act, the District Court’s power to order a new trial was limited (in terms similar to those in the current section) but the then terms of s 127 of the Act conferred an additional right to apply to the Supreme Court for a new trial. That additional right was removed by the 1995 amendments to the District Court Act (amendments that also removed the “point of law” restriction on the more general right of appeal). Although that right was restored in 2008 by the insertion of s 127A , the current terms of s 126 of the District Court Act confine the District Court’s power to order a new trial after judgment to situations where (a) a jury has not delivered its verdict, (b) the parties consent, (c) the application is made on the day of a jury's verdict, or (d) in the case of a non-jury trial, application is made within 21 days of judgment. The terms of s 126 recognise the distinction between the verdict of the jury and the entry of judgment. Once the jury has returned its verdict, and the verdict is “entered” (which for the purposes of the section can be constituted by the judge's associate recording the details of the verdict on the court file), the court cannot order a new trial pursuant to s 126(2) . After judgment, the court may exercise the power conferred by s 126(1) to order a new trial if any of the requirements set out in subparas (a) , (b) or (c) have been made out: see generally Lithgow District Hospital v Miller (NSWCA, Priestley, Handley and Sheller JJA, No 40563/93, 8 December 1994, unreported, BC9404877).
Legislation cited in [DCA s 126.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 126.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR 51.53.

The discretionary power to order a new trial conferred by s 126 is not unfettered and should be exercised only in accordance with established principles: Costains (Aust) Pty Ltd v Atkinson (NSWCA, Gleeson CJ, Kirby P and Sheller JA, No 40261/93, 5 October 1995, unreported, BC9505463); Brown v Dean [1910] AC 373 ; Murtagh v Barry (1890) 24 QBD 632 ; Ex parte Holt (1894) 1 WN 87; Hill v Cooke (1958) 75 WN (NSW) 82. The power is therefore subject to the same limitations as those that govern the granting of new trials by the Supreme Court: Brown v Dean [1910] AC 373 ; Poy v Darcey (1898) 15 WN (NSW) 34 . The application for a new trial may be based upon alleged errors of fact as well as errors of law: Nominal Defendant v Hook (1962) 113 CLR 641; 36 ALJR 190; [1963] ALR 183; BC6200660 ; Nieborak v Barker [1963] NSWR 965 see also How v London and North Western Railway Co [1891] 2 QB 496; see generally UCPR 51.53 and notes [51.53.5] and following. An order for a new trial may be limited to the question of damages: Willis v David Jones Ltd (1934) 34 SR (NSW) 303; 51 WN (NSW) 106 ; Bakalidis v Hill [1967] 2 NSWR 742; (1968) 87 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 64.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 127] s 127 Right of appeal to Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Right of appeal to Supreme Court

p.text: A party who is dissatisfied with a Judge's or a Judicial Registrar’s judgment or order in an action may appeal to the Supreme Court.
[subs (1) am Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 23 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 4, effective 17 May 2006]
The following appeals lie only by leave of the Supreme Court:
an appeal from an interlocutory judgment or order,
an appeal from a judgment or order as to costs only,
an appeal from a final judgment or order, other than an appeal:
that involves a matter at issue amounting to or of the value of $100,000 or more, or
that involves (directly or indirectly) any claim, demand or question to or respecting any property or civil right amounting to or of the value of $100,000 or more.
an appeal from a judgment or order on an application for summary judgment under the rules.
an appeal from an order made with the consent of the parties.
[subs (2) am Act 47 of 1997 s 5 and Sch 3 ; Act 141 of 1997 s 2 and Sch 1 ; Act 49 of 1998 s 2 and Sch 10 ; Act 99 of 2002 s 3 and Sch 3, effective 20 December 2002]
In any other case, an appeal lies as of right.
[s 127 subst Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 127.5] Appeal powers of the Supreme Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 127.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 Div 7, Division 8, Part 4, s 127, subs (2)(c), s 139, ss 142A–142F, s 4.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 s 48(2)(f).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 28.2, UCPR r 51.22.
(NSW) Crimes Act 1900 s 562WC.
(NSW) Children (Care and Protection) Act 1987 s 81.
(NSW) Children and Young Persons (Care and Protection) Act 1998 s 91.
(NSW) Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 67.

heading.title: Appeal powers of the Supreme Court

p.text: An appeal under s 127 lies to the Supreme Court. By virtue of the provisions of SCA s 48(2)(f) such appeals are assigned to the Court of Appeal and a party is no longer able to make a specific application to the Supreme Court for an order granting a new trial.

The section draws a clear distinction between those matters where there is an appeal as of right and those where leave of the court is required. Where there are potential statutory restrictions on the right to appeal, UCPR r 51.22 requires an appellant to file an affidavit demonstrating that the restrictions do not apply: see [51.22.5] . The phrase "at issue" in the monetary value limitation contained in subs (2)(c) means truly at issue in the proceedings. The limitation the provision contains cannot be circumvented by the mere assertion of a higher valued claim. An appeal lies as of right only if there is a genuine prospect that the successful appellant would change the result of the first instance proceedings by $100,000 or more. In other words, the realistic worth of the claim must exceed $100,000, otherwise leave to appeal is required: Gillard v Hunter Wire Products Pty Ltd (t/as Hunter Screen Products) (No 2) [2001] NSWCA 450; BC200107626 at [10]–[13] cited in Pegela Pty Ltd v Oates [2010] NSWCA 186; BC201005554 at [58]–[63] ; Jensen v Ray [2011] NSWCA 247 ; BC201106672 at [5]–[15] per Brereton J.

“Action” is defined in DCA s 4 as “an action in the Court, but does not include any proceedings under Division 8 of Part 3 or under Part 4 ”. This definition is supplemented by some provisions that require some proceedings to be regarded as an “action” for some purposes: see DCA s 139 (relating to Div 7 of Pt 3). The following types of proceedings have not been regarded as “actions” for the purposes of the right of appeal conferred by DCA s 127 :

Proceedings heard by the court within its special civil jurisdiction created by DCA ss 142A–142F : Victims Compensation Fund Corporation v District Court of New South Wales (1997) 92 A Crim R 224; BC9700737 .

An appeal lodged by a claimant for victims compensation: Grzybowicz v Smiljanic [1980] 1 NSWLR 627 cited with approval in Saddi v Victims Compensation Fund (NSWCA, Mason P, Sheller and Powell JJA, No 40717/97, 2 March 1998, unreported, BC9707655).

A statutory appeal to the District Court: Cook v Head [1976] 1 NSWLR 176 (costs order in appeal proceedings under the Commercial and Private Inquiry Agents Act 1963); Spruill v D-G of the Dept of Community Services [2001] NSWCA 413; BC200107138 (order under Children and Young Persons (Care and Protection) Act 1998 s 81 or s 91 ): Druett v D-G of Community Services [2001] NSWCA 126; BC200101954 ; Sullivan v St George Community Housing Ltd [2010] NSWCA 248; BC201007148 at [39] per Basten JA (no right of appeal under s 127 from a decision of the District Court exercising appellate jurisdiction under s 67 of the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 (NSW). Such appellate proceedings are not proceedings “in an action” for the purposes of s 127 ); Muldoon v Church of England Children’s Homes Burwood [2011] NSWCA 46; BC201101466 at [38]–[42] and [65] (no statutory right of appeal from the District Court to the Court of Appeal arising under s 67 of the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 (NSW).
The act of the District Court in referring (or declining to refer) a question of contempt to the Supreme Court: Johnson v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (2005) 62 NSWLR 309; [2005] NSWCA 17; BC200500868 .

Where the matter in dispute does not involve a judgment or order “in an action” the only available remedy is an application for judicial review: Cook v Head [1976] 1 NSWLR 176 ; Director-General, Attorney-General's Dept v District Court (NSW) (1993) 32 NSWLR 409 at 411 and Torrealba v District Court of New South Wales (1996) 40 NSWLR 327; BC9604114 ; Druett v D-G of Community Services [2001] NSWCA 126 ; BC200101954 at [16] and following.

“Judgment” is defined in DCA s 4 to mean “judgment given or entered up in the action”. A decision which is made by a judge of the court following the determination of a separate question (see UCPR r 28.2 ) constitutes "judgment or order" for the purposes of the section: Damjanovic v Sharpe Hume & Co (Services) Pty Ltd [2001] NSWCA 130; BC200102037 . A judgment or order of a judge made after a trial with a jury in the District Court, even though referred to by the judge as a “verdict” constitutes a “judgment or order”: Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2009) 237 CLR 268; 254 ALR 637; [2009] HCA 18; BC200903186 .

A third party who is joined to proceedings as a third party is a "party to the action" for the purposes of the section. Such a party will be bound by a judgment which is adverse to its interests and may therefore appeal pursuant to the provisions of s 127 . Similarly, a party joined as a cross defendant will have a right to appeal under s 127 : Insurance Exchange of Australasia Group v Dooley (2000) 50 NSWLR 222; [2000] NSWCA 159; BC200004689 .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 127.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR 51.18, UCPR 51.53.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 75A.
A notice of appeal should identify the grounds of appeal specifically and as briefly as the nature of the matter permits: see UCPR 51.18 and [51.18.5] .
The commonly encountered grounds of appeal, and the related grounds on which an application for a new trial may be made, are listed and discussed in the notes to UCPR 51.53 and also SCA s 75A .
An appeal against a decision of a Judicial Registrar of the District Court lies to the Court of Appeal rather than review by the District Court: Bi v Mourad [2010] NSWCA 17; BC201000654 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 127A] s 127A Appeal after jury trial

p.text: Where, in any proceedings in the Court, there is a trial of the proceedings or of any issue in the proceedings with a jury, an application for:
the setting aside of a verdict or judgment, or
a new trial, or
the alteration of a verdict by increasing or reducing any amount of debt, damages or other money,
shall be by appeal to the Supreme Court.
An appeal under this section lies as of right.
[s 127A insrt Act 53 of 2008 s 3 and Sch 12[2], effective 1 July 2008]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 127A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 102.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 126, s 127, s 127(1).

The section confers a right of appeal to the Supreme Court from jury trials in the District Court that is equivalent to the right of appeal in SCA s 102 . The section overcame the effect of the decision of the majority of the Court of Appeal in Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2007) 70 NSWLR 395; [2007] NSWCA 375; BC200711460 — prior to its subsequent reversal in Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2009) 237 CLR 268; 254 ALR 637; [2009] HCA 18; BC200903186 at [35]ff (the High Court held that a verdict pronounced by the trial judge after a jury trial was a judgment or order within the meaning of DCA s 127(1) ). Even without the present section an appeal lies under s 127 of the District Court Act from the refusal of an application for a new trial under DCA s 126 : Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2007) 70 NSWLR 395; [2007] NSWCA 375; BC200711460 at [87], [88], [94] and [99] ; Keramianakis v Regional Publishers Pty Ltd (2009) 237 CLR 268; 254 ALR 637; [2009] HCA 18; BC200903186 . In addition, the circumstances that might justify an application for a new trial under DCA s 126 might also involve a separate judgment or order to which the right of appeal in DCA s 127(1) also applies. Construing DCA s 127(1) as conferring a right of appeal in such a case would accord with the decision of the High Court in Nominal Defendant v Hook (1962) 113 CLR 641; [1963] ALR 183; BC6200660 , without the need to attempt to distinguish cases such as Wilson v Sunlight Goldmining Co (1891) 12 NSWLR 237 and Bullock v Stewart (1913) 13 SR (NSW) 471; 30 WN (NSW) 113 ; where it was held that an application for a new trial could not be entertained by the Supreme Court if it was based upon the same grounds as a prior unsuccessful application to the District Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 128] s 128 Stay of proceedings on appeal to Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Stay of proceedings on appeal to Supreme Court

p.text: This section applies if, after judgment in an action, the Court orders that proceedings be stayed during the period within which an appeal may be brought.
If during that period:
an appeal is brought in respect of proceedings that have been stayed, and

security is given to the satisfaction of the registrar for the amount of the judgment debt (if any) payable by the appellant, including an amount assessed by the registrar in respect of any costs forming part of the judgment debt,
the stay of proceedings is to continue until the appeal is disposed of or until the Court or the Supreme Court otherwise orders.
An appeal does not operate to stay proceedings in any other way.
This section does not affect the operation of section 156(1) .
[s 128 subst Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 128.5] Stay of proceedings pending appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 128.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 subs (2).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR 51.44.

The District Court may order a stay of proceedings under the present section, subject to any contrary order that may be made by the Court of Appeal. Where a stay is ordered under the present section subs (2) contemplates that the respondent will be required to provide security for both the judgment debt and the appeal costs. The considerations relevant to the exercise of the stay power are discussed in the notes to UCPR 51.44 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 129] s 129 Agreement not to appeal

p.text: An appeal shall not lie to the Supreme Court from any ruling, order, direction or decision if before the ruling, order, direction or decision is pronounced the parties agree in writing, signed by themselves or their Australian legal practitioner, that the ruling, order, direction or decision shall be final.
[s 129 am Act 1 of 1975 s 3 ; Act 103 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1; Act 58 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3.4[2], effective 20 June 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 130] s 130 Whether application or appeal to Supreme Court is as of right

leg:heading.title: Whether application or appeal to Supreme Court is as of right

p.text: [s 130 rep Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 131] s 131 Stay of proceedings on an application or appeal to Supreme Court

leg:heading.title: Stay of proceedings on an application or appeal to Supreme Court

p.text: [s 131 rep Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]
